author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
Regarding VDF hardware, who (which class of agents) is expected to possess this? Are we expecting commodity hardware to include these within the decade, for instance, or is it something that only block builders under PBS may have access to? 

The purpose of the hardware would primarily be for cheaper/faster *verification*, right?

author: sky.cactus
content: In most VDF schemes, you need to know what the fastest possible execution is, but you don't actually need to execute that fast.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you know that the fastest someone on Earth could calculate the VDF is 10 seconds, that means you can *know* that at least 10 seconds have passed once it is solved.  Most systems designed with VDFs in mind only need that lower bound, it is acceptable if 1000 seconds has passed.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, if you want a random number generator you may set the lower bound at `n` blocks (12 seconds per block).  Someone commits to say blockhash as the VDF seed and then they find out what their random number is after the VDF is complete.  In many cases it is acceptable to have that random number revealed far in the future (way more than `n*12 seconds`), so someone can start crunching away at the VDF on their laptop and find out what the random number is maybe `n*100` seconds later or something.

author: sky.cactus
content: If there is a very common VDF and the VDF has a reward for computing it, you may get some actor to actually buy/build the necessary hardware to compute it quickly because it allows them to make money by doing so, but this usually isn't a hard requirement of the system's design.
